questions.text: Match the following: Septoplasty Lautenslager operation Functional endoscopic sinus surgery Stapedotomy Otosclerosis Fungal sinusitis Atrophic rhinitis Deviated nasal septum
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A4, B3, C2, D1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A. Septoplasty → 4. Deviated nasal septum : Septoplasty is a surgical procedure to correct a deviated nasal septum , which can cause nasal obstruction and breathing difficulties.
  • • A. Septoplasty → 4. Deviated nasal septum
  • • deviated nasal septum
  • • B. Lautenslager operation → 3. Atrophic rhinitis : The Lautenslager operation is a surgical procedure used in the treatment of atrophic rhinitis , a condition where the nasal mucosa degenerates, leading to a wide nasal cavity and crusting.
  • • B. Lautenslager operation → 3. Atrophic rhinitis
  • • atrophic rhinitis
  • • C. Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) → 2. Fungal sinusitis : FESS is a minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat conditions like fungal sinusitis , chronic sinusitis, and other sinus-related disorders.
  • • C. Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) → 2. Fungal sinusitis
  • • fungal sinusitis
  • • D. Stapedotomy → 1. Otosclerosis : Stapedotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat otosclerosis , a condition in which abnormal bone growth in the middle ear causes hearing loss by affecting the stapes bone.
  • • D. Stapedotomy → 1. Otosclerosis
  • • otosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Septoplasty is performed for correcting deviated nasal septum . Lautenslager operation is a treatment for atrophic rhinitis . FESS is a minimally invasive surgery often used to treat fungal sinusitis and other sinus diseases. Stapedotomy is the surgical intervention for otosclerosis , a cause of conductive hearing loss.
  • ➤ Septoplasty is performed for correcting deviated nasal septum .
  • ➤ Septoplasty
  • ➤ deviated nasal septum
  • ➤ Lautenslager operation is a treatment for atrophic rhinitis .
  • ➤ Lautenslager operation
  • ➤ atrophic rhinitis
  • ➤ FESS is a minimally invasive surgery often used to treat fungal sinusitis and other sinus diseases.
  • ➤ FESS
  • ➤ fungal sinusitis
  • ➤ Stapedotomy is the surgical intervention for otosclerosis , a cause of conductive hearing loss.
  • ➤ Stapedotomy
  • ➤ otosclerosis

questions.text: After a road traﬃc accident, a patient presented with watery discharge from 1 nostril that cannot be sniﬀed back. Find the true statement regarding the condition:

options.label: A
options.text: Beta 2 transferrin in the discharge is important in diagnosing the condition

options.label: B
options.text: Handkerchief will not be stiﬀened by this discharge

options.label: C
options.text: A central reddish spot surrounded by a yellow halo can be seen when a drop of discharge is kept on a paper

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta 2 transferrin is a highly specific test for identifying CSF rhinorrhea . CSF leakage does not stiffen fabric like regular nasal mucus, and the halo sign is a classical indicator of CSF mixed with blood. These findings are crucial for diagnosing CSF rhinorrhea, particularly in post-traumatic settings.
  • ➤ Beta 2 transferrin is a highly specific test for identifying CSF rhinorrhea .
  • ➤ Beta 2 transferrin
  • ➤ CSF rhinorrhea
  • ➤ CSF leakage does not stiffen fabric like regular nasal mucus, and the halo sign is a classical indicator of CSF mixed with blood. These findings are crucial for diagnosing CSF rhinorrhea, particularly in post-traumatic settings.
  • ➤ halo sign

questions.text: A young professional trumpet blower presented with left sided neck swelling which makes a hissing sound on compression. What is the sign you can notice?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bryce

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bryce sign is characteristic of laryngocele , where neck swelling produces a hissing sound upon compression due to trapped air. This is common in individuals like trumpet players who use increased lung pressure.
  • ➤ Bryce sign
  • ➤ laryngocele

questions.text: Which of the following surgeries should be performed below the age of 6 years?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cochlear implantation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cochlear implantation should be performed before the age of 6 to maximize auditory and language development in children with hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following does not require immediate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nasal bone fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasal bone fractures typically do not require immediate management, as intervention is often delayed to allow swelling to subside.

questions.text: A case of RTA with multiple temporal bone fractures has presented with facial nerve palsy. On imaging, a portion of the facial canal was found to be oedematous and a bony spicule was found to be impinging on the nerve. A facial nerve decompression was planned. Which of the following surgery needs to be done before going to open the fallopian canal ? (patient had intact lacrimation and stapedial reflex but absent taste sensation)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mastoidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of facial nerve palsy caused by temporal bone fractures, mastoidectomy is the appropriate surgical procedure to access the facial nerve, especially in the vertical mastoid segment, for decompression.
  • ➤ mastoidectomy

questions.text: A patient presented with hardness of hearing. His otoscopy image is given below. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myringosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myringosclerosis is characterized by calcified patches on the tympanic membrane that can contribute to conductive hearing loss. It is typically seen following healed perforations or chronic otitis media, but does not cause a perforation.
  • ➤ Myringosclerosis

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought with suspected hearing problem. On otoscopy, following is seen. What is the possible finding on impedance audiometry in the same patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In otitis media with effusion (OME) , type B tympanogram is commonly observed on impedance audiometry due to the presence of fluid in the middle ear, which restricts the mobility of the tympanic membrane.
  • ➤ otitis media with effusion (OME)
  • ➤ type B tympanogram

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought with complaints of stridor and cough. He appears weak and has low grade fever. What is the sign you see on his x-ray ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Steeple sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The steeple sign on an x-ray indicates subglottic narrowing, characteristic of croup . Croup commonly presents with stridor, barking cough, and low-grade fever in young children.
  • ➤ steeple sign
  • ➤ croup

questions.text: What is the grade of retraction you see in the given picture ?
questions.correct_answer: A. Sade grade 2 on right side
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sade grade 2 on right side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In assessing tympanic membrane retraction, Sade’s classification provides a useful grading system. Sade grade 2 retraction is characterized by the tympanic membrane making contact with the promontory without severe adherence.

questions.text: What is the grade of retraction you see in the given picture ?
questions.correct_answer: B. Tos grade 2 on left side
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tos grade 2 on left side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tos classification is a system used to grade tympanic membrane retraction. Tos grade 2 signifies moderate retraction without deep adherence, which is crucial for assessing the extent of tympanic membrane pathology and planning appropriate management.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of ear pain. He had mild fever, cold and cough. Otoscopy image is shown below. What is the possible diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myringitis bullosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myringitis bullosa is diagnosed based on the presence of bullae on the tympanic membrane, often associated with viral infections and upper respiratory symptoms. It presents with ear pain and characteristic bullous changes on otoscopy.
  • ➤ Myringitis bullosa

questions.text: A 8-month-old child is brought with the following finding which started 2 days back. She had ear discharge episodes from last 4 months. What is possible diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Postauricular abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A postauricular abscess is a common complication of chronic otitis media and mastoiditis, presenting as a swelling behind the ear. It is associated with ear discharge and requires urgent treatment to prevent further complications.
  • ➤ postauricular abscess

questions.text: A patient who underwent submucous resection 5 years back, now presented with mild whistling like sounds from his nose. His DNE picture is shown. What is the possible diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Septal perforation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Septal perforation can result from nasal surgeries such as submucous resection or septoplasty. The condition may cause whistling sounds during breathing and requires careful assessment. It is typically visualized as a hole in the nasal septum on endoscopy.
  • ➤ Septal perforation

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of auditory pathway

options.label: A
options.text: Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex medial → lateral geniculate body → inferior colliculus

options.label: B
options.text: Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex inferior → lateral lemniscus → inferior geniculate body

options.label: C
options.text: Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex superior → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus

options.label: D
options.text: Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex lateral → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex

questions.correct_answer: C. Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex superior → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cochlear nucleus → olivary complex superior → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is: cochlear nucleus → superior olivary complex → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex .
  • ➤ cochlear nucleus → superior olivary complex → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents to an ENT consultant with a history of right ear discharge for 3 days, accompanied by ear pain, hearing loss, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. On examination, the external auditory canal is filled with purulent discharge, and a soft, irregular reddish mass is observed. After attempting to clear the discharge, the consultant visualizes an intact tympanic membrane. There is slight bleeding on contact with the soft tissue swelling during the procedure. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following statements is true regarding the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Intratympanic steroid injection is one of the treatment options for this condition

options.label: B
options.text: Ga-67 scan is done to assess the extent of bony involvement

options.label: C
options.text: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the causative organism

questions.correct_answer: C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the causative organism
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the causative organism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant otitis externa is an aggressive infection typically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in diabetic or immunocompromised patients. The diagnosis should be suspected when there is ear pain, discharge, and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal. Treatment primarily involves antipseudomonal antibiotics, and imaging may be required to assess bone involvement.
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text: Development of SCALA MEDIA of membranous labyrinth is from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pars inferior

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The scala media or cochlear duct , part of the membranous labyrinth, is derived from the pars inferior , and plays a vital role in hearing by housing the organ of Corti. The pars superior contributes to the development of structures involved in balance, such as the utricle and semicircular canals.
  • ➤ scala media
  • ➤ cochlear duct
  • ➤ pars inferior
  • ➤ pars superior

questions.text: Match the following Acute epiglottitis Furunculosis Otomycosis Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis Aspergillus niger Staphylococcus aureus Aspergillus fumigatus Hemophilus influenzae
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A4, B2, C1, D3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Each of these conditions is linked to specific pathogens. Hemophilus influenzae is responsible for acute epiglottitis, Staphylococcus aureus causes furunculosis, Aspergillus niger is linked to otomycosis, and Aspergillus fumigatus is commonly found in allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.
  • ➤ Hemophilus influenzae
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger
  • ➤ Aspergillus fumigatus

questions.text: True statement:

options.label: A
options.text: Multiple painful perforations seen in tubercular otitis media

options.label: B
options.text: Pars flaccida is weaker due to absence of fibrous layer

options.label: C
options.text: Handle of malleus is shortened in retracted tympanic membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Malleus ossicle has got no muscular attachments

questions.correct_answer: B. Pars flaccida is weaker due to absence of fibrous layer
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pars flaccida is weaker due to absence of fibrous layer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane is weaker due to the absence of the middle fibrous layer, making it more susceptible to certain ear pathologies.
  • ➤ pars flaccida

questions.text: A patient with post traumatic facial nerve palsy has presented with absent taste sensation on anterior 2/3rd part of his tongue. His stapedial reflex was checked and it was present. Schirmer’s test for lacrimation was done and it was negative .i.e., lacrimation was normal. Most probable site of facial nerve lesion could be at?

options.label: A
options.text: Translabyrinthine portion (the portion of facial nerve lying at the level of inner ear)

options.label: B
options.text: Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear

options.label: C
options.text: Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear

options.label: D
options.text: In the parotid substance where it divides into its 5 terminal branches

questions.correct_answer: C. Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lesion in the vertical portion of the facial nerve on the posterior wall of the middle ear can result in loss of taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, while sparing both stapedial reflex and lacrimation .
  • ➤ vertical portion
  • ➤ loss of taste
  • ➤ stapedial reflex
  • ➤ lacrimation

questions.text: Boundaries of facial recess Facial nerve horizontal part Chorda tympani Incus Vertical descending part of facial nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) b, c, d

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial recess is bounded by the vertical part of the facial nerve , the chorda tympani , and the incus . This space is important in surgical procedures involving the middle ear, such as cochlear implantation, as it allows access to the middle ear and mastoid without disturbing key structures.
  • ➤ facial recess
  • ➤ vertical part of the facial nerve
  • ➤ chorda tympani
  • ➤ incus

questions.text: Following does not cause sensorineural hearing loss
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Superior semicircular dehiscence syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCD) typically leads to conductive hearing loss , as opposed to the sensorineural hearing loss caused by conditions like acoustic neuroma , presbycusis , and Meniere’s disease .
  • ➤ Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCD)
  • ➤ conductive hearing loss
  • ➤ sensorineural hearing loss
  • ➤ acoustic neuroma
  • ➤ presbycusis
  • ➤ Meniere’s disease

questions.text: True regarding inverted papilloma
questions.correct_answer: B. Most common site middle meatus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Most common site middle meatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inverted papilloma most commonly arises from the middle meatus and grows inward into the stroma. The tumor is locally aggressive and has a potential for malignancy, so surgical excision is critical for treatment.
  • ➤ Inverted papilloma
  • ➤ middle meatus

questions.text: Sialolithiasis is most common in submandibular gland because

options.label: A
options.text: Stenson’s duct travels up against the gravity

options.label: B
options.text: Secretions of submandibular gland are thicker than other glands

questions.correct_answer: B. Secretions of submandibular gland are thicker than other glands
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Secretions of submandibular gland are thicker than other glands

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sialolithiasis is most common in the submandibular gland due to its thicker secretions, which are more prone to forming stones. The duct associated with this gland is Wharton’s duct , not Stenson's duct, which belongs to the parotid gland.
  • ➤ Sialolithiasis
  • ➤ submandibular gland
  • ➤ Wharton’s duct

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with unilateral hardness of hearing and ear block sensation. Rinne was negative on affected side. Cone of light was absent and handle of malleus was foreshortened. On impedance audiometry, which of the following type of curve is most likely to appear?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Type C tympanogram indicates negative middle ear pressure, which is commonly seen in cases of Eustachian tube dysfunction and tympanic membrane retraction
  • ➤ Type C tympanogram
  • ➤ Eustachian tube dysfunction

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presented to ENT clinic with complaint of profuse epistaxis that is difficult to control. Most probable suspected diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) should be suspected in adolescent males who present with profuse epistaxis, as it is the most common benign tumor in this age group and is highly vascular, making the bleeding difficult to control.

questions.text: Laryngeal paralysis – true statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Vocal cord lies in cadaveric position in unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

options.label: B
options.text: Both vocal cords lie in full abduction in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

options.label: C
options.text: Emergency tracheostomy is done in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

options.label: D
options.text: Kashima procedure is done in unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

questions.correct_answer: C. Emergency tracheostomy is done in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Emergency tracheostomy is done in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy , the vocal cords lie in the paramedian position, causing airway obstruction that may require an emergency tracheostomy to secure the airway. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy results in a vocal cord resting in the paramedian position, and the Kashima procedure is used to treat bilateral vocal cord paralysis by increasing the airway opening.
  • ➤ bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • ➤ Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • ➤ Kashima procedure

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought to an ENT consultant. Antenatal history showed that the mother had TORCH infection. Perinatal history revealed that the child was born at 32 weeks of gestational age with only 1.5kg body weight. Immediately after that, he had severe respiratory distress and was kept on a ventilator in an ICU for continuous 5 days. He was also aﬀected with pathological jaundice. On otoscopy, the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane were found to be normal. Impedance audiometry showed A type of curve. What next investigations would you prefer to advice to this child ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infants with risk factors such as prematurity, TORCH infections, NICU stay for more than 5 days, and pathological jaundice should undergo both Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) to evaluate for sensorineural hearing loss early.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came with complaints of hardness of hearing in right ear which was gradually progressive. On examination, tympanic membrane was intact but slight haziness was noticed. Rinne was negative on right side and weber lateralised to the right ear. A pure tone audiometry was advised. Which of the following audiogram belongs to the above patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of otosclerosis or other causes of conductive hearing loss , pure tone audiometry typically shows a gap between air conduction and bone conduction thresholds, with bone conduction being better.
  • ➤ otosclerosis
  • ➤ conductive hearing loss
  • ➤ air conduction
  • ➤ bone conduction

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought with complaint of noisy breathing. On examination, inspiratory stridor was found. Videolaryngoscopy showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Laryngomalacia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia, characterized by an omega-shaped epiglottis and inspiratory stridor, is the most common cause of noisy breathing in infants and results from supraglottic airway collapse during inspiration.
  • ➤ omega-shaped epiglottis

questions.text: Crus commune is formed by the union of:
questions.correct_answer: A. Superior and Posterior semicircular canals
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Superior and Posterior semicircular canals

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The crus commune is formed by the union of the superior and posterior semicircular canals , contributing to the anatomy of the inner ear’s vestibular system.
  • ➤ crus commune
  • ➤ superior
  • ➤ posterior semicircular canals

questions.text: While doing surgery for intractable BPPV, surgeon accidentally cuts the parent nerve instead of cutting the actual nerve. Which nerve the surgeon has cut ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inferior vestibular nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For intractable BPPV , surgery is aimed at the inferior vestibular nerve , which innervates the posterior semicircular canal . Misidentifying and cutting this nerve could worsen vestibular symptoms instead of treating them.
  • ➤ BPPV
  • ➤ inferior vestibular nerve
  • ➤ posterior semicircular canal

questions.text: Match the following: Abductor Adductor Tensor closer of laryngeal inlet cricothyroid posterior cricoarytenoid interarytenoid – transverse interarytenoid – oblique
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) a2, b3, c1, d4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle responsible for abducting the vocal cords, while the cricothyroid tenses the vocal cords for pitch adjustment. The interarytenoid muscles (transverse and oblique) play roles in adduction and laryngeal inlet closure.
  • ➤ posterior cricoarytenoid
  • ➤ cricothyroid
  • ➤ interarytenoid muscles

questions.text: Most common site of grommet insertion in a child suffering from otitis media with effusion:

options.label: A
options.text: Antero inferior quadrant of tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Postero inferior quadrant of tympanic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Antero superior quadrant of tympanic membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Postero superior quadrant of tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. Antero inferior quadrant of tympanic membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antero inferior quadrant of tympanic membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The antero-inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane is the preferred site for grommet insertion in children with otitis media with effusion , ensuring safety and effective drainage while avoiding damage to important middle ear structures.
  • ➤ antero-inferior quadrant
  • ➤ otitis media with effusion

questions.text: Match the following: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma Meniere’s disease Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis Chronic suppurative otitis media HRCT temporal bone contrast MRI electrocochleography CT nose and pns
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A2, B3, C4, D1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is best evaluated with contrast MRI . Meniere’s disease is diagnosed with electrocochleography to detect inner ear fluid changes. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis is evaluated using CT nose and PNS to detect sinus involvement. Chronic suppurative otitis media is often assessed using HRCT of the temporal bone to evaluate any bony changes or complications.
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is best evaluated with contrast MRI .
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
  • ➤ contrast MRI
  • ➤ Meniere’s disease is diagnosed with electrocochleography to detect inner ear fluid changes.
  • ➤ Meniere’s disease
  • ➤ electrocochleography
  • ➤ Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis is evaluated using CT nose and PNS to detect sinus involvement.
  • ➤ Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis
  • ➤ CT nose and PNS
  • ➤ Chronic suppurative otitis media is often assessed using HRCT of the temporal bone to evaluate any bony changes or complications.
  • ➤ Chronic suppurative otitis media
  • ➤ HRCT of the temporal bone

questions.text: Sequence of angles of head movements turned sequentially stepwise in epley manouevre:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 45 degree → 30 degree → 90 degree → 90 degree

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Epley maneuver consists of specific head movements in a sequence: 45 degrees → 30 degrees → 90 degrees → 90 degrees . These movements help reposition displaced otoliths in patients with BPPV.
  • ➤ Epley maneuver
  • ➤ 45 degrees → 30 degrees → 90 degrees → 90 degrees

questions.text: Following is not seen in transverse temporal bone fracture (otic capsule involving):
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transverse temporal bone fractures (involving the otic capsule) are associated with symptoms like facial nerve palsy , vertigo , and tinnitus due to the involvement of inner ear structures and nearby cranial nerves.
  • ➤ Transverse temporal bone fractures
  • ➤ facial nerve palsy
  • ➤ vertigo
  • ➤ tinnitus

questions.text: Identify the structural anomaly in the CT scan image of a patient:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of nasal obstruction, a combination of structural anomalies like concha bullosa , deviated nasal septum , and inferior turbinate hypertrophy can contribute to the patient's symptoms.
  • ➤ concha bullosa
  • ➤ deviated nasal septum
  • ➤ inferior turbinate hypertrophy

questions.text: Following figure shows blood supply of nose. Which numbered artery is ligated first in intractable epistaxis:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of intractable epistaxis , the sphenopalatine artery is often the first to be ligated, as it is a major contributor to the blood supply of the nasal cavity.
  • ➤ intractable epistaxis
  • ➤ sphenopalatine artery

questions.text: Following is a part of hypopharynx:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pyriform fossa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hypopharynx includes the pyriform fossa , posterior pharyngeal wall , and the postcricoid area , which are key anatomical regions involved in swallowing and phonation.
  • ➤ hypopharynx
  • ➤ pyriform fossa
  • ➤ posterior pharyngeal wall
  • ➤ postcricoid area

questions.text: Identify the location of radio-opaque foreign body in the given x-ray:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In interpreting neck x-rays, it is important to recognize normal anatomical structures such as the hyoid bone , epiglottis , and ossified cartilages of the larynx to avoid mistaking them for foreign objects. Misinterpretation can lead to unnecessary interventions.
  • ➤ hyoid bone
  • ➤ epiglottis
  • ➤ ossified cartilages

questions.text: Identify the sign shown in the picture:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Holman Miller sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Holman Miller sign is indicative of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) and is characterized by the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus . It is an important radiological sign to recognize in young males presenting with nasopharyngeal masses.
  • ➤ Holman Miller sign
  • ➤ juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)
  • ➤ anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus

questions.text: Find the false statement among the following:

options.label: A
options.text: True positive fistula test indicates perilymph fistula

options.label: B
options.text: False positive fistula test indicates congenital syphilis

options.label: C
options.text: True negative fistula test indicates late stages of meniere’s disease

options.label: D
options.text: False negative fistula test indicates dead labyrinth

questions.correct_answer: C. True negative fistula test indicates late stages of meniere’s disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) True negative fistula test indicates late stages of meniere’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A false negative fistula test can occur in conditions where the inner ear is non-functional, while a false positive fistula test may occur in conditions like congenital syphilis due to fibrous attachments. True positive fistula tests suggest the presence of a perilymph fistula .
  • ➤ false negative fistula test
  • ➤ false positive fistula test
  • ➤ congenital syphilis
  • ➤ True positive fistula tests
  • ➤ perilymph fistula

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with hardness of hearing in both ears from last 5 years which was gradually deteriorating. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane looked normal. Rinne was positive on both sides and weber test showed no response (no sounds were heard in any ear when tuning fork was kept on the forehead). Impedance showed A type curve with intact stapedial reflex. He was also subjected to pure tone audiometry. Among the following audiograms, what could be the correct one in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with gradual hearing loss, a normal tympanic membrane , positive Rinne test (indicating sensorineural hearing loss), and no response on the Weber test , the condition is likely sensorineural hearing loss , and in elderly patients, this is commonly due to presbycusis .
  • ➤ normal tympanic membrane
  • ➤ positive Rinne test
  • ➤ Weber test
  • ➤ sensorineural hearing loss
  • ➤ presbycusis

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with unilateral hearing loss. Oto-endoscopic picture is shown below. Rinne was negative and weber lateralised to the same ear. Clinically next structure to be observed in the patient is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an older patient presenting with unilateral conductive hearing loss, it is crucial to consider nasopharyngeal carcinoma as a possible underlying cause, particularly if the clinical picture includes tympanic membrane changes suggestive of Eustachian tube obstruction. In such cases, nasopharyngeal visualization, typically using nasopharyngoscopy, is an essential next step to identify any masses or obstructions affecting the Eustachian tube.
  • ➤ nasopharyngeal carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following description best fits cholesteatoma?

options.label: A
options.text: A cholesterol containing tumour in the middle ear

options.label: B
options.text: Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative

options.label: C
options.text: Endodermal derivative in a space enclosed by ectodermal derivative

options.label: D
options.text: Mesodermal tissue proliferation in middle ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholesteatoma is an abnormal growth of ectodermal squamous epithelium in the middle ear, a space typically lined with endodermal mucosa .
  • ➤ Cholesteatoma
  • ➤ ectodermal squamous epithelium
  • ➤ endodermal mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding atrophic rhinitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Atrophy of nerve elements cause merciful anosmia

options.label: B
options.text: Nasal mucosa appears pale due to atrophy

options.label: C
options.text: Turbinate bones resorption causes widening of cavity

options.label: D
options.text: Diseased mucosa removed in Young’s operation

questions.correct_answer: D. Diseased mucosa removed in Young’s operation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diseased mucosa removed in Young’s operation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Young's operation is a treatment for atrophic rhinitis that involves closing the nasal cavities to promote healing. It does not involve the removal of diseased mucosa.
  • ➤ Young's operation
  • ➤ not

questions.text: Identify the laryngeal pathologies in the given sequence of images:

options.label: A
options.text: Vocal polyp, Vocal nodule, Vocal granuloma, Reinke’s edema

options.label: B
options.text: Vocal nodule, Vocal polyp, Reinke’s edema, Vocal granuloma

options.label: C
options.text: Reinke’s edema, Vocal granuloma, Vocal polyp, Vocal nodule

options.label: D
options.text: Vocal granuloma, Reinke’s edema, Vocal nodule, Vocal polyp

questions.correct_answer: B. Vocal nodule, Vocal polyp, Reinke’s edema, Vocal granuloma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vocal nodule, Vocal polyp, Reinke’s edema, Vocal granuloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vocal nodule, Vocal polyp, Reinke’s edema, Vocal granuloma

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the anatomical and developmental aspects of the pinna (auricle) is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The entire pinna and outer cartilaginous external auditory canal are composed of a single piece of yellow elastic cartilage.

options.label: B
options.text: The area of the pinna devoid of cartilage, known as the incisura terminalis, is utilized in Lempert’s endaural approach to ear surgery.

options.label: C
options.text: The lobule of the ear pinna, which contains fat covered by skin, is an area devoid of cartilage and often used for fat grafts.

options.label: D
options.text: Improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryological development results in the formation of pre-auricular sinuses, which always require surgical excision, regardless of symptomatology.

questions.correct_answer: D. Improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryological development results in the formation of pre-auricular sinuses, which always require surgical excision, regardless of symptomatology.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryological development results in the formation of pre-auricular sinuses, which always require surgical excision, regardless of symptomatology.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pre-auricular sinuses do not always require surgical excision. Treatment is based on the presence of symptoms such as recurrent infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a known history of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with a 3-week history of persistent otorrhea from her right ear, despite treatment with topical antibiotics. On examination, multiple small granulations are seen in the middle ear, and the tympanic membrane has multiple perforations. The patient's audiogram shows a conductive hearing loss in the affected ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tubercular otitis media

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubercular otitis media is characterized by multiple tympanic membrane perforations , painless persistent otorrhea , and granulation tissue in the middle ear. It is important to suspect this condition in patients with a history of tuberculosis and chronic ear symptoms unresponsive to conventional antibiotic treatments.
  • ➤ multiple tympanic membrane perforations
  • ➤ painless persistent otorrhea
  • ➤ granulation tissue
